summary: This paper investigates the temperature dependence of protein folding kinetics, particularly focusing on the Arrhenius behavior when corrected for the effects of temperature on protein stability. The study uses a model system, protein L, to demonstrate that the anomalous temperature dependence of folding is primarily due to the temperature-dependent interactions that stabilize proteins. The research provides insights into the intrinsic temperature dependence of folding separate from stability effects by manipulating denaturant concentration.
formulas: k~T,@gnd#! = DF*exp(-((DHU2TS - T*DSU2TS + DCp:U2TS*(T - T0 - T*ln(T/T0)) - mU2TS*@gnd#) / (R*T)) - ((DHN2TS - T*DSN2TS + DCp:N2TS*(T - T0 - T*ln(T/T0)) - mN2TS*@gnd#) / (R*T)))
DG~T,den! = DG~T! - m@den# = DH - T*DS + DCp@(T - T0 - T*ln(T/T0)) - m@den#
relationships: The logarithm of the folding rate is a linear function of 1/T on constant stability contours in the temperature-denaturant plane.
The temperature dependence of the folding and unfolding rates are modeled by combining the free energy of folding and a simple transition-state theory expression.
The stability-corrected Arrhenius plots suggest that the non-Arrhenius behavior observed for folding kinetics is entirely a result of the temperature dependence of the forces driving folding.
variables: k~T,@gnd#!: Rate constant for folding and unfolding reactions
DF: Pre-exponential factor in the Arrhenius equation
DHU2TS, DHN2TS: Enthalpy change for folding and unfolding
DSU2TS, DSN2TS: Entropy change for folding and unfolding
DCp:U2TS, DCp:N2TS: Change in heat capacity for folding and unfolding
mU2TS, mN2TS: Denaturant dependence for folding and unfolding
DG~T,den!: Free energy of folding at temperature T and denaturant concentration den
DG~T!: Free energy of folding at temperature T
m@den#: Effect of denaturant concentration on free energy
D: Pre-exponential factor specific to protein folding
DGTS: Free energy of activation for the transition state
key_ideas: Protein folding kinetics exhibit a simple Arrhenius behavior when corrected for protein stability effects due to temperature.
The study uses experimental data from protein L to model the kinetics of folding and unfolding across different temperatures and denaturant concentrations.

The findings challenge the super Arrhenius temperature dependence predicted by models based on a rough energy landscape, suggesting instead that the observed temperature dependence is due to interactions stabilizing the protein.
